summary: Translocation means a change in location. It often refers to genetics, when part of a chromosome is transferred to another chromosome. Chromosomes are structures that carry genes, our units of heredity. When a translocation occurs, it can cause flaws in chromosomes. In another type of translocation, two chromosomes trade pieces with each other.Genetic translocations can cause serious disorders, including a type of leukemia.

title: Transplant rejection
summary: Transplant rejection is a process in which a transplant recipient's immune system attacks the transplanted organ or tissue.
alternative_names: Graft rejection; Tissue/organ rejection

title: Transplant services
summary: Transplantation is a procedure that is done to replace one of your organs with a healthy one from another person. The surgery is only one part of a complex, long-term process.Several experts will help you prepare for the procedure, and make sure you are comfortable before, during, and after surgery.

title: Transposition of the great arteries
summary: Transposition of the great arteries (TGA) is a heart defect that occurs from birth (congenital). The two major arteries that carry blood away from the heart -- the aorta and the pulmonary artery -- are switched (transposed).
alternative_names: d-TGA; Congenital heart defect - transposition; Cyanotic heart disease - transposition; Birth defect - transposition; Transposition of the great vessels; TGV

title: Transurethral resection of the prostate
summary: Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) is a surgery to remove the inside part of the prostate gland. It is done in order to treat symptoms of an enlarged prostate.
alternative_names: TURP; Prostate resection - transurethral

title: Transurethral resection of the prostate - discharge
summary: You had transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) surgery to treat an enlarged prostate. This article tells you how to take care of yourself at home after the procedure.
alternative_names: TURP - discharge; Prostate resection - transurethral - discharge

title: Transvaginal ultrasound
summary: Transvaginal ultrasound is a test used to look at a woman's uterus, ovaries, tubes, cervix, and pelvic area.Transvaginal means across or through the vagina. The ultrasound probe will be placed inside the vagina during the test.
alternative_names: Endovaginal ultrasound; Ultrasound - transvaginal; Fibroids - transvaginal ultrasound; Vaginal bleeding - transvaginal ultrasound; Uterine bleeding - transvaginal ultrasound; Menstrual bleeding - transvaginal ultrasound; Infertility - transvaginal ultrasound; Ovarian - transvaginal ultrasound; Abscess - transvaginal ultrasound

title: Transverse myelitis
summary: Transverse myelitis is a condition caused by inflammation of the spinal cord. As a result, the covering (myelin sheath) around the nerve cells is damaged. This disturbs the signals between spinal nerves and rest of the body. Transverse myelitis can cause pain, muscle weakness, paralysis, and bladder or bowel problems.
alternative_names: TM; Acute transverse myelitis; Secondary transverse myelitis; Idiopathic transverse myelitis

title: Traumatic amputation
summary: Traumatic amputation is the loss of a body part, usually a finger, toe, arm, or leg, that occurs as the result of an accident or injury.
alternative_names: Loss of a body part

title: Traumatic brain injury
summary: A traumatic brain injury (TBI) can occur when the head hits an object, or a moving object strikes the head. There are three types of TBI:Mild TBI, also called a concussionModerate TBISevere TBIA TBI can affect how the brain works. The degree of impaired brain function and other symptoms and how long they will last depends on how severe the TBI is. A TBI may lead to headaches, changes in alertness, loss of consciousness, memory loss, and changes in thinking. Moderate to severe TBIs can cause life-long health problems.
alternative_names: Concussion; Brain injury - concussion; Traumatic brain injury - concussion; Closed head injury - concussion

title: Traumatic events and children
summary: One in four children experiences a traumatic event by the time they are 18 years old. Traumatic events can be life threatening and are bigger than what your child should ever have to experience.Learn what to watch for in your child and how to take care of your child after a traumatic event. Get professional help if your child is not recovering.
alternative_names: Stress - traumatic events in children

title: Traumatic injury of the bladder and urethra
summary: Traumatic injury of the bladder and urethra involves damage caused by an outside force.
alternative_names: Injury - bladder and urethra; Bruised bladder; Urethral injury; Bladder injury; Pelvic fracture; Urethral disruption; Bladder perforation

title: Traveler's diarrhea diet
summary: Traveler's diarrhea causes loose, watery stools. People can get traveler's diarrhea when they visit places where the water is not clean or the food is not handled safely. This can include developing countries in Latin America, Africa, the Middle East, and Asia.This article tells you what you should eat or drink if you have traveler's diarrhea.
alternative_names: Diet - traveler's diarrhea; Diarrhea - traveler's - diet; Gastroenteritis - traveler's

title: Traveler's guide to avoiding infectious diseases
summary: You can stay healthy during travel by taking the right steps to protect yourself before you go. You can also do things to help prevent disease while you are traveling. Most infections you catch while traveling are minor. In rare cases, however, they can be severe, or even deadly.Diseases vary in different places in the world. You will need to take different preventive steps, depending on where you are going. The following things should be considered:Insects and parasitesLocal climateSanitationThe best public sources for up-to-date travel information are the:Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) -- www.cdc.gov/travelWorld Health Organization (WHO) -- www.who.int/health-topics/travel-and-health#tab=tab_1BEFORE TRAVELTalk to your health care provider or visit a travel clinic 4 to 6 weeks before you leave for your trip. You may need several vaccinations. Some of these need time to work.You also may need to update your vaccinations. For example, you may need "booster" vaccines for:COVID-19Diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis (Tdap)Influenza (flu)Measles - mumps - rubella (MMR)PolioYou also may need vaccines for diseases that are not commonly found in North America. Examples of recommended vaccines include:Hepatitis AHepatitis BMeningococcalTyphoidCertain countries have required vaccinations. You may need proof that you have had this vaccine in order to enter the country.Yellow fever vaccination is required to enter certain Sub-Saharan, Central African, and South American countries.Meningococcal vaccination is required to enter Saudi Arabia for the Hajj pilgrimage.For a complete list of country requirements, check the CDC or WHO websites.People who may have different vaccine requirements include:ChildrenOlder people People with weakened immune systems or HIVPeople who expect to be in contact with certain animalsWomen who are pregnant or breastfeedingCheck with your provider or local travel clinic.PREVENTING MALARIAMalaria is a serious disease that spreads by the bite of certain mosquitoes, typically biting between dusk and dawn. It occurs mainly in tropical and subtropical climates. Malaria can cause high fevers, shaking chills, flu-like symptoms, and anemia. There are 4 types of malaria parasites.If you are traveling to an area where malaria is common, you may need to take medicines that prevent the disease. These medicines are taken before you leave, during your travel, and for a short period after you return. How well the medicines work varies. Some strains of malaria are resistant to some preventive medicines. You should also take steps to prevent insect bites.ZIKA VIRUSZika is a virus passed to humans by the bite of infected mosquitoes. Symptoms include fever, joint pain, rash, and red eyes (conjunctivitis). The mosquitoes that spread Zika are the same type that spread dengue fever and chikungunya virus. These mosquitoes usually feed during the day. No vaccine exists for preventing Zika.There is believed to be a link between mothers with Zika infection and babies born with microcephaly and other birth defects. Zika can spread from a mother to her baby in the uterus (in utero) or at the time of birth. A man with Zika can spread the disease to his sex partners. There have been reports of Zika spreading through blood transfusion.Before 2015, the virus was found mainly in Africa, Southeast Asia, and the Pacific Islands. It has now spread to many states and countries including:BrazilCaribbean IslandsCentral AmericaMexicoNorth AmericaSouth AmericaPuerto RicoThe disease has been found in certain regions of the United States. For the most up-to-date information, please visit the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's (CDC) website -- www.cdc.gov/zika.To prevent getting the Zika virus, take steps to avoid mosquito bites. Sexual transmission of the virus can be prevented by using condoms or not having sex with a person who is possibly infected.PREVENTING INSECT BITESTo prevent against bites from mosquitoes and other insects:Wear insect repellent when you are outdoors, but use it safely. Conventional repellents include DEET and picaridin. Some biopesticide repellents are oil of lemon eucalyptus (OLE), PMD, and IR3535.You may also need to use a bed mosquito net while you sleep.Wear trousers and long-sleeved shirts, particularly at dusk.Sleep only in screened areas.Do not wear perfumes.FOOD AND WATER SAFETYYou can get some types of infections by eating or drinking contaminated food or water. There is a high risk of infection from eating undercooked or raw foods.Stay away from the following foods:Cooked food that has been allowed to cool (such as from street vendors)Fruit that has not been washed with clean water and then peeledRaw vegetablesSaladsUnpasteurized dairy foods, such as milk or cheeseDrinking untreated or contaminated water can lead to infection. Only drink the following liquids:Canned or unopened bottled beverages (water, juice, carbonated mineral water, soft drinks)Drinks made with boiled water, such as tea and coffeeDo not use ice in your drinks unless it is made from purified water. You can purify water by boiling it or by treating it with certain chemical kits or water filters.OTHER STEPS TO PREVENT INFECTIOUS DISEASESClean your hands often. Use soap and water or an alcohol-based cleanser to help prevent infection.Do not stand or swim in fresh-water rivers, streams, or lakes that have sewage or animal feces in them. This can lead to infection. Swimming in chlorinated pools is safe most of the time.WHEN TO CONTACT A MEDICAL PROFESSIONALDiarrhea can sometimes be treated with rest and fluids. Your provider may give you an antibiotic to take on your trip in case you get sick with severe diarrhea while traveling.Get medical care right away if:Diarrhea does not go awayYou develop a high fever or become dehydratedContact your provider when you return home if you were sick with a fever while traveling.

title: Traveling with breathing problems
summary: If you have breathing problems such as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), you can travel safely if you take a few precautions.
alternative_names: Oxygen - travel; Collapsed lung - travel; Chest surgery - travel; COPD - travel; Chronic obstructive airways disease - travel; Chronic obstructive lung disease - travel; Chronic bronchitis - travel; Emphysema - travel

title: Traveling with children
summary: Traveling with children presents special challenges. It disrupts familiar routines and imposes new demands. Planning ahead, and involving children in the planning, may lessen the stress of travel.
alternative_names: Ear pain - flying; Ear pain - airplane

title: Trazodone overdose
summary: Trazodone is an antidepressant medicine. Sometimes, it is used as a sleep aid and to treat agitation in people with dementia. Trazodone overdose occurs when someone takes more than the normal or recommended amount of this medicine, either by accident or on purpose.This article is for information only. DO NOT use it to treat or manage an actual overdose. If you or someone you are with overdoses, call your local emergency number (such as 911), or your local poison control center can be reached directly by calling the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222) from anywhere in the United States.
alternative_names: Trazadone hydrochloride

title: Treacher Collins syndrome
summary: Treacher Collins syndrome is a genetic condition that leads to problems with the structure of the face. Most cases are not passed down through families.
alternative_names: Mandibulofacial dysostosis; Treacher Collins-Franceschetti syndrome

title: Treatment for childhood cancer - long-term risks
summary: Today's cancer treatments help cure most children with cancer. These treatments also may cause health problems later on. These are called "late effects."Late effects are treatment side effects that appear several months or years after treatment for cancer. Late effects can impact one or more areas of the body. Effects can be mild to severe.Whether your child will have late effects depends on the type of cancer and the treatments your child has. Being aware of your child's risk of long-term health problems can help you follow-up with health care providers and detect any problems early.
alternative_names: Childhood cancer - late effects

title: Tremor
summary: A tremor is a type of shaking movement. A tremor is most often noticed in the hands and arms. It may affect any body part, including the head, tongue, or vocal cords.
alternative_names: Shaking; Tremor - hand; Hand tremor; Tremor - arms; Kinetic tremor; Intention tremor; Postural tremor; Essential tremor

title: Tremor - self-care
summary: A tremor is a type of shaking in your body. Most tremors are in the hands and arms. However, they may affect any body part, even your head or voice.
alternative_names: Shaking - self-care; Essential tremor - self-care; Familial tremor - self-care

title: Trench mouth
summary: Trench mouth is an infection that causes swelling (inflammation) and ulcers in the gums (gingivae). The term trench mouth comes from World War I, when this infection was common among soldiers "in the trenches."
alternative_names: Vincent's stomatitis; Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis (ANUG); Vincent disease

title: Trichinosis
summary: Trichinosis is an infection with the roundworm Trichinella spiralis.
alternative_names: Parasite infection - trichinosis; Trichiniasis; Trichinellosis; Roundworm - trichinosis

title: Trichomoniasis
summary: Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis.
alternative_names: Trichomonas vaginitis; STD - trichomonas vaginitis; STI - trichomonas vaginitis; Sexually transmitted infection - trichomonas vaginitis; Cervicitis - trichomonas vaginitis

title: Trichorrhexis nodosa
summary: Trichorrhexis nodosa is a common hair problem in which thickened or weak points (nodes) along the hair shaft cause your hair to break off easily.
alternative_names: Hair shaft fracture; Brittle hair; Fragile hair; Hair breakage

title: Trichotillomania
summary: Trichotillomania is hair loss from repeated urges to pull or twist the hair until it breaks off. People are unable to stop this behavior, even as their hair becomes thinner.
alternative_names: Trichotillosis; Compulsive hair pulling

title: Tricuspid atresia
summary: Tricuspid atresia is a type of heart disease that is present at birth (congenital heart disease), in which the tricuspid heart valve is missing or abnormally developed. The defect blocks blood flow from the right atrium to the right ventricle. Other heart or vessel defects are usually present at the same time.
alternative_names: Tri atresia; Valve disorder - tricuspid atresia; Congenital heart - tricuspid atresia; Cyanotic heart disease - tricuspid atresia

title: Tricuspid regurgitation
summary: Blood that flows between different chambers of your heart must pass through a heart valve. These valves open up enough so that blood can flow through. They then close, keeping blood from flowing backward.The tricuspid valve separates the right lower heart chamber (the right ventricle) from the right upper heart chamber (right atrium).Tricuspid regurgitation is a disorder in which this valve does not close tight enough. This problem causes blood to flow backward into the right atrium when the right ventricle contracts.
alternative_names: Tricuspid insufficiency; Heart valve - tricuspid regurgitation; Valvular disease - tricuspid regurgitation

title: Trigeminal neuralgia
summary: Trigeminal neuralgia (TN) is a nerve disorder. It causes a stabbing or electric shock-like pain in parts of the face.
alternative_names: Tic douloureux; Cranial neuralgia; Facial pain - trigeminal; Facial neuralgia; Trifacial neuralgia; Chronic pain - trigeminal; Microvascular decompression - trigeminal

title: Trigger finger
summary: Trigger finger occurs when a finger or thumb gets stuck in a bent position, as if you were squeezing a trigger. Once it gets unstuck, the finger pops straight out, like a trigger being released.In severe cases, the finger cannot be straightened. Surgery is needed to correct it.
alternative_names: Digital stenosing tenosynovitis; Trigger digit; Trigger finger release; Locked finger; Digital flexor tenosynovitis

title: Triglyceride level
summary: The triglyceride level is a blood test to measure the amount of triglycerides in your blood. Triglycerides are a type of fat.Your body makes some triglycerides. Triglycerides also come from the food you eat. Extra calories are turned into triglycerides and stored in fat cells for later use.A test for high blood cholesterol levels is a related measurement and usually done at the same time.
alternative_names: Triacylglycerol test

title: Trisodium phosphate poisoning
summary: Trisodium phosphate is a strong chemical. Poisoning occurs if you swallow, breathe in, or spill large amounts of this substance on your skin.This article is for information only. DO NOT use it to treat or manage an actual poison exposure. If you or someone you are with has an exposure, call the local emergency number (such as 911), or the local poison control center can be reached directly by calling the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222) from anywhere in the United States.
alternative_names: Sodium orthophosphate poisoning; Trisodium orthophosphate poisoning; TSP poisoning

title: Trisomy 13
summary: Trisomy 13 (also called Patau syndrome) is a genetic disorder in which a person has 3 copies of genetic material from chromosome 13, instead of the usual 2 copies. Rarely, the extra material may be attached to another chromosome (translocation).
alternative_names: Patau syndrome

title: Trisomy 18
summary: Trisomy 18 is a genetic disorder in which a person has a third copy of material from chromosome 18, instead of the usual 2 copies. Rarely, the extra material may be attached to another chromosome (translocation). Most cases are not passed down through families. Instead, the problems that lead to this condition occur in either the sperm or the egg that forms the fetus.
alternative_names: Edwards syndrome

title: Tropical sprue
summary: Tropical sprue is a condition that occurs in people who live in or visit tropical areas for extended periods of time. It impairs nutrients from being absorbed from the intestines.Tropical sprue (TS) is a syndrome characterized by acute or chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and malabsorption of nutrients.

title: Troponin test
summary: A troponin test measures the levels of troponin T or troponin I proteins in the blood. These proteins are released when the heart muscle has been damaged, such as occurs with a heart attack. The more damage there is to the heart, the greater the amount of troponin T and I there will be in the blood.
alternative_names: TroponinI; TnI; TroponinT; TnT; Cardiac-specific troponin I; Cardiac-specific troponin T; cTnl; cTnT

title: Truncus arteriosus
summary: Truncus arteriosus is a rare type of heart disease in which a single blood vessel (truncus arteriosus) comes out of the right and left ventricles, instead of the normal 2 vessels (pulmonary artery and aorta). It is present at birth (congenital heart disease).There are different types of truncus arteriosus.
alternative_names: Truncus

title: Trypsin and chymotrypsin in stool
summary: Trypsin and chymotrypsin are substances released from the pancreas during normal digestion. When the pancreas does not produce enough trypsin and chymotrypsin, smaller-than-normal amounts can be seen in a stool sample.This article discusses the test to measure trypsin and chymotrypsin in stool.
alternative_names: Stool - trypsin and chymotrypsin

title: Trypsinogen test
summary: Trypsinogen is a substance that is normally produced in the pancreas and released into the small intestine. Trypsinogen is converted to trypsin. Then it starts the process needed to break down proteins into their building blocks (called amino acids).A test can be done to measure the amount of trypsinogen in your blood.
alternative_names: Serum trypsin; Trypsin-like immunoreactivity; Serum trypsinogen; Immunoreactive trypsin

title: Tryptophan
summary: Tryptophan is an amino acid needed for normal growth in infants and for the production and maintenance of the body's proteins, muscles, enzymes, and neurotransmitters. It is an essential amino acid. This means your body cannot produce it, so you must get it from your diet.

title: TSH test
summary: A TSH test measures the amount of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) in your blood. TSH is produced by the pituitary gland. It prompts the thyroid gland to make and release thyroid hormones into the blood.
alternative_names: Thyrotropin; Thyroid stimulating hormone; Hypothyroidism - TSH; Hyperthyroidism - TSH; Goiter - TSH

title: TSI test
summary: TSI stands for thyroid stimulating immunoglobulin. TSIs are antibodies that tell the thyroid gland to become more active and release excess amounts of thyroid hormone into the blood. A TSI test measures the amount of thyroid stimulating immunoglobulin in your blood.
alternative_names: TSH receptor stimulating antibody; Thyroid stimulating immunoglobulin; Hypothyroidism - TSI; Hyperthyroidism - TSI; Goiter - TSI; Thyroiditis - TSI

title: Tubal ligation
summary: Tubal ligation is surgery to close a woman's fallopian tubes. (It is sometimes called "tying the tubes.") The fallopian tubes connect the ovaries to the uterus. A woman who has this surgery can no longer get pregnant. This means she is "sterile."
alternative_names: Sterilization surgery - female; Tubal sterilization; Tube tying; Tying the tubes; Hysteroscopic tubal occlusion procedure; Contraception - tubal ligation; Family planning - tubal ligation

title: Tubal ligation - discharge
summary: Tubal ligation is surgery to close the fallopian tubes. After a successful tubal ligation, a woman cannot get pregnant. This article tells you how to care for yourself after leaving the hospital.
alternative_names: Sterilization surgery - female - discharge; Tubal sterilization - discharge; Tube tying - discharge; Tying the tubes - discharge; Contraception - tubal

title: Tubal ligation reversal
summary: Tubal ligation reversal is surgery done to allow a woman who has had her tubes tied (tubal ligation) to become pregnant again. The fallopian tubes are reconnected in this reversal surgery. A tubal ligation cannot always be reversed if there is too little tube left or if it is damaged.
alternative_names: Tubal re-anastomosis surgery; Tuboplasty

title: Tubercle
summary: A tubercle is a small rounded point of a bone. Less often, it refers to a nodule attached to bone, mucous membrane (moist layer lining parts of the body), or skin.

title: Tuberous sclerosis
summary: Tuberous sclerosis is a genetic disorder that affects the skin, brain/nervous system, kidneys, heart, and lungs. The condition can also cause tumors to grow in the brain. These tumors have a tuber or root-shaped appearance.
alternative_names: Bourneville disease

title: Tularemia
summary: Tularemia is a bacterial infection in wild rodents. The bacteria are passed to humans through contact with tissue from the infected animal. The bacteria can also be passed by ticks, biting flies, and mosquitoes.
alternative_names: Deerfly fever; Rabbit fever; Pahvant Valley plague; Ohara disease; Yato-byo (Japan); Lemming fever

title: Tularemia blood test
summary: Tularemia blood test checks for infection caused by bacteria called Francisella tularensis (F tularensis). The bacteria causes the disease tularemia.
alternative_names: Tularemia test; Serology for Francisella tularensis

title: Tumor
summary: A tumor is an abnormal growth of body tissue. Tumors can be cancerous (malignant) or noncancerous (benign).
alternative_names: Mass; Neoplasm

title: Turbinate surgery
summary: The inside walls of the nose have 3 pairs of long thin bones covered with a layer of tissue that can expand. These bones are called nasal turbinates.Allergies or other nasal problems can cause the turbinates to swell and block airflow. Surgery can be done to open blocked airways and improve your breathing.
alternative_names: Turbinectomy; Turbinoplasty; Turbinate reduction; Nasal airway surgery; Nasal obstruction - turbinate surgery

title: Turner syndrome
summary: Turner syndrome is a rare genetic condition in which a female does not have the usual pair of X chromosomes.
alternative_names: Bonnevie-Ullrich syndrome; Gonadal dysgenesis; Monosomy X; XO

title: Turning patients over in bed
summary: Changing a patient's position in bed every 2 hours helps keep blood flowing. This helps the skin stay healthy and prevents bedsores.Turning a patient is a good time to check the skin for redness and sores.
alternative_names: Roll patients in bed

title: Turpentine oil poisoning
summary: Turpentine oil comes from a substance in pine trees. Turpentine oil poisoning occurs when someone swallows turpentine oil or breathes in the fumes. Breathing these fumes on purpose is sometimes called "huffing" or "bagging." It is a member of a class of compounds known as hydrocarbons. Exposure to hydrocarbons, both intentional and unintentional, is a common problem resulting in thousands of calls to poison control centers each year.This article is for information only. DO NOT use it to treat or manage an actual poison exposure. If you or someone you are with has an exposure, call the local emergency number (such as 911), or the local poison control center can be reached directly by calling the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222) from anywhere in the United States.

title: Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome
summary: Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome is a rare condition that occurs only in identical twins while they are in the womb.Watch this video about:Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome
alternative_names: TTTS; Fetal transfusion syndrome

title: Tympanometry
summary: Tympanometry is a test used to detect problems in the ear drum and middle ear.
alternative_names: Tympanogram; Otitis media - tympanometry; Effusion - tympanometry; Immittance testing

title: Type 1 diabetes
summary: Type 1 diabetes is a lifelong (chronic) disease in which there is a high level of sugar (glucose) in the blood.
alternative_names: Insulin-dependent diabetes; Juvenile onset diabetes; Diabetes - type 1; High blood sugar - type 1 diabetes

title: Type 2 diabetes
summary: Type 2 diabetes is a lifelong (chronic) disease in which there is a high level of sugar (glucose) in the blood. Type 2 diabetes is the most common form of diabetes.
alternative_names: Diabetes - type II; Adult-onset diabetes; Diabetic - type 2 diabetes; Oral hypoglycemic - type 2 diabetes; High blood sugar - type 2 diabetes

title: Type 2 diabetes - self-care
summary: Type 2 diabetes is a life-long (chronic) disease. If you have type 2 diabetes, the insulin your body normally makes has trouble transmitting a signal to muscle and fat cells. Insulin is a hormone made by the pancreas to control blood sugar. When your body's insulin isn't able to signal correctly, the sugar from food stays in the blood and the sugar (glucose) level can get too high.Most people with type 2 diabetes are overweight when they're diagnosed. The changes in the way the body handles blood sugar that lead to type 2 diabetes usually happen slowly.Everyone with diabetes should receive proper education and support about the best ways to manage their diabetes. Ask your health care provider about seeing a certified diabetes care and education specialist (often called a diabetes educator).
alternative_names: Type 2 diabetes - managing

title: Type 2 diabetes - what to ask your doctor
summary: Type 2 diabetes, once diagnosed, is a lifelong disease that causes a high level of sugar (glucose) in your blood. It can damage your organs. It can also lead to a heart attack or stroke and cause many other health problems. You can do many things to control your symptoms, prevent damage due to diabetes, and make your life better.Below are questions you may want to ask your health care provider to help you take care of your diabetes.
alternative_names: What to ask your provider about diabetes - type 2

title: Type V glycogen storage disease
summary: Type V (five) glycogen storage disease (GSD V) is a rare inherited condition in which the body is not able to break down glycogen. Glycogen is an important source of energy that is stored in all tissues, especially in the muscles and liver.GSD V is also called McArdle disease.
alternative_names: Myophosphorylase deficiency; Muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency; PYGM deficiency

title: Types of chemotherapy
summary: Chemotherapy is the use of medicine to treat cancer. Chemotherapy kills cancer cells. It may be used to cure cancer, help keep it from spreading, or reduce symptoms. In some cases, people are treated with a single type of chemotherapy. But often, people get more than one type of chemotherapy at a time. This helps attack the cancer in different ways. Targeted therapy and immunotherapy are other cancer treatments that use medicine to treat cancer.Standard chemotherapy works by killing cancer cells and some normal cells. Targeted treatment and immunotherapy zero in on specific targets (molecules) in or on cancer cells.

title: Types of health care providers
summary: This article describes health care providers involved in primary care, nursing care, and specialty care.
alternative_names: Physicians; Nurses; Health care providers; Doctors; Pharmacists

title: Types of hormone therapy
summary: Hormone therapy (HT) uses one or more hormones to treat symptoms of menopause. HT uses estrogen, progestin (a type of progesterone), or both. Sometimes testosterone is also added.
alternative_names: HRT- types; Estrogen replacement therapy - types; ERT- types of hormone therapy; Hormone replacement therapy - types; Menopause - types of hormone therapy; HT - types; Menopausal hormone types

title: Types of ileostomy
summary: You had an injury or disease in your digestive system and needed an operation called an ileostomy. The operation changed the way your body gets rid of waste (stool, feces, or poop).Now you have an opening called a stoma in your belly. Waste will pass through the stoma into a pouch that collects it. You will need to take care of the stoma and empty the pouch several times a day.
alternative_names: Ileostomy - types; Standard ileostomy; Brooke ileostomy; Continent ileostomy; Abdominal pouch; End ileostomy; Ostomy; Inflammatory bowel disease - ileostomy and your ileostomy type; Crohn disease - ileostomy and your ileostomy type; Ulcerative colitis - ileostomy and your ileostomy type

title: Typhoid fever
summary: Typhoid fever is an infection that causes fever, diarrhea, and a rash. It is most commonly caused by bacteria called Salmonella typhi (S typhi).
alternative_names: Enteric fever

title: Typhus
summary: Typhus is a bacterial disease spread by lice or fleas.
alternative_names: Murine typhus; Epidemic typhus; Endemic typhus; Brill-Zinsser disease; Jail fever

title: A1C
summary: If you are being tested for Type 2 diabetes, your doctor gives you an A1C test. The test is also used to monitor your A1C levels.
alternative_names: Glycohemoglobin; HbA1C; Hemoglobin A1C test

title: Abdominal Pain
summary: Stomach aches can be painful. Find out what might be the cause of your abdominal pain.
alternative_names: Bellyache

title: Abortion
summary: An abortion is a medical procedure to end a pregnancy. It uses medicine or surgery to remove the embryo or fetus and placenta from the uterus.
alternative_names: Induced Abortion

title: Abscess
summary: Abscesses are filled with pus and can occur anywhere on your body. They can be painful. Learn about types of abscesses and how they are treated.

title: Acne
summary: Looking for ways to fight unsightly zits? Both teens and adults can get acne. Learn what causes pimples and blackheads and how to manage them.
alternative_names: Pimples; Zits

title: Acoustic Neuroma
summary: An acoustic neuroma is a benign tumor that grows on the cranial nerve that connects the ear to the brain. It can affect hearing and balance nerves.
alternative_names: Acoustic neurilemmoma; Acoustic neurinoma; Auditory tumor; Vestibular schwannoma

title: Acupuncture
summary: Are you considering acupuncture to treat pain? Find out about how this type of traditional Chinese medicine might help you.

title: Acute Bronchitis
summary: Bronchitis is an inflammation of the airways that carry air to your lungs. Learn about acute bronchitis symptoms, causes, and treatment

title: Acute Flaccid Myelitis
summary: Acute flaccid myelitis (AFM) is a rare but serious neurologic disease. It mostly affects children. Learn about its possible causes and symptoms.
alternative_names: AFM

title: Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia
summary: Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL) or Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia is a cancer of the white blood cells. Learn more about symptoms and treatment.
alternative_names: ALL; Acute lymphoblastic leukemia

title: Acute Myeloid Leukemia
summary: Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) is a cancer of the white blood cells. AML usually gets worse quickly if it is not treated. Read more.
alternative_names: AML; ANLL; Acute myelogenous leukemia

title: Addison Disease
summary: Your adrenal glands makes hormones. Adrenal insufficiency or Addison disease happens if the adrenal glands don't make enough hormones. Read more.
alternative_names: Adrenal insufficiency; Adrenocortical hypofunction; Hypocortisolism

title: Adenoids
summary: Your adenoids are high up in your throat. They trap germs coming in your mouth and nose. Learn about enlarged adenoids, a common problem in children.

title: Adhesions
summary: Abdominal surgery is the main cause of adhesions but not the only one. Learn about the signs, symptoms, and causes this type of scar tissue.
alternative_names: Abdominal adhesions

title: Adrenal Gland Cancer
summary: Tumors can affect adrenal glands. Most adrenal gland tumors are benign. Types of tumors include Neuroblastoma and Pheochromocytoma.

title: Adrenal Gland Disorders
summary: Adrenal gland disorders, such as Cushing's Syndrome and Addison's Disease, happen when your glands make too much or not enough hormones.

title: Advance Directives
summary: Advance directives, or living wills, inform your family about your wishes if you become too ill to let them know. Find out more.

title: After Surgery
summary: Are you concerned about post-surgery side effects or after surgery care? Learn about how to care for incisions, control pain, and more.
alternative_names: Postoperative care; Recovery from surgery

title: Air Pollution
summary: Did you know that air pollution can happen both inside buildings and outdoors?  Get the facts how air pollution effects your health.

title: Alcohol
summary: Many people drink alcohol. Drinking too much can take a serious toll on your health. It's important to know how alcohol affects you and how much is too much.
alternative_names: Drinking

title: Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD)
summary: An alcohol use disorder (AUD) is drinking that causes distress and harm. AUD can range from mild to severe (alcoholism). Learn the signs that you may have a problem with drinking.
alternative_names: Alcohol Abuse; Alcohol dependence; Alcoholism

title: Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) Treatment
summary: An alcohol use disorder (AUD) is drinking that causes distress and harm. Learn about the medicines and behavioral therapies that treat AUD.
alternative_names: Alcohol Abuse Treatment; Alcoholism Treatment

title: Allergy
summary: An allergy is a reaction by your immune system. Substances that cause reactions include pollen and food. Find the full list of allergies and symptoms.
alternative_names: Hypersensitivity

title: Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency
summary: Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency is an inherited condition that raises your risk for lung and liver disease. Learn about the symptoms and treatment.
alternative_names: AATD; Alpha-1; Inherited emphysema

title: Alzheimer's Caregivers
summary: Caring for someone who has Alzheimer's Disease can be stressful and overwhelming. It's important to take care of yourself. Learn how to find support.

title: Alzheimer's Disease
summary: Alzheimer's disease is a brain disorder that slowly destroys memory and thinking skills. It's the most common cause of dementia among older adults.
alternative_names: AD

title: Amblyopia
summary: Learn about amblyopia, or "lazy eye," the most common cause of visual problems in children. It happens when an eye fails to work properly with the brain.
alternative_names: Lazy eye

title: American Indian and Alaska Native Health
summary: Every racial or ethnic group has specific health concerns. On this page, you'll find links to health issues that affect American Indians and Alaska Natives.
alternative_names: Alaska Native health; American Indian health

title: Amino Acid Metabolism Disorders
summary: Disorders like phenylketonuria (PKU) and maple syrup urine disease cause problems with how your body uses proteins. Learn more about them.

title: Amyloidosis
summary: Amyloidosis is a rare condition that can affect different organs of the body. Find out about amyloidosis treatment and symptoms.

title: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis
summary: ALS stands for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, also called Lou Gehrig's disease. ALS affects the nervous system, causing muscle problems. Find out how.
alternative_names: ALS; Lou Gehrig's disease

title: Anabolic Steroids
summary: Thinking about using anabolic steroids to build muscles or improve your athletic performance? Think again. Misusing them is not legal or safe. It can cause long-term health problems.
alternative_names: Anabolic-androgenic steroids; Performance-enhancing drugs

title: Anal Cancer
summary: Anal cancer is rare. HPV is one of the most common causes. Find out more about anal cancer symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment.

title: Anal Disorders
summary: Anal disorders include hemorrhoids, fistulas, and abscesses. Learn about which anal conditions are minor and those that are more serious.
alternative_names: Anorectal diseases

title: Anaphylaxis
summary: Anaphylaxis or anaphylactic shock is a serious allergic reaction. It can begin very quickly, and symptoms may be life-threatening. Read the symptoms.
alternative_names: Anaphylactic shock

title: Anatomy
summary: Anatomy is the science that studies the structure of the body. Learn about the organs and body parts.

title: Anemia
summary: Anemia occurs when your blood doesn't carry enough oxygen to the rest of your body. Read about conditions that lead to it and treatments available.
alternative_names: Iron poor blood

title: Anesthesia
summary: Local, regional, general - all are types of anesthesia. Learn about how anesthesia reduces or blocks pain before a surgery.

title: Aneurysms
summary: An aneurysm is a bulge in the wall of an artery. It can develop and grow for years without causing any symptoms. Learn about tests and treatment.

title: Angina
summary: Angina is chest pain or discomfort when there is not enough blood flow to your heart muscle. Learn about angina symptoms and treatment.

title: Angioplasty
summary: Angioplasty is a procedure to restore blood flow through narrow or blocked arteries. Learn about how stents and angioplasty work.
alternative_names: Balloon angioplasty; Coronary angioplasty; Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)

title: Animal Bites
summary: Wild animals might attack if they are threatened or acting protective. Attacks by pets are more common. Learn how to avoid both types of animal bites.
alternative_names: Cat bites; Dog bites

title: Animal Diseases and Your Health
summary: You may know that some animal diseases can have an effect on humans. Find out more about animal diseases and your health.
alternative_names: Zoonoses

title: Ankle Injuries and Disorders
summary: Ankle injuries and ankle disorders can affect tendons and cartilage. Learn about different kinds of ankle problems including sprains and fractures.

title: Ankylosing Spondylitis
summary: Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of arthritis. It causes inflammation between vertebrae and in the joints between spine and pelvis. Learn more.
alternative_names: Rheumatoid spondylitis

title: Anthrax
summary: You probably won't have to worry about getting anthrax disease.  We offer information about anthrax symptoms, causes, vaccine, and treatment.

title: Antibiotic Resistance
summary: Antibiotics can save lives. But when they are not used properly they can become less effective. Use them only when necessary to combat antibiotic resistance.

title: Antibiotics
summary: Used properly, antibiotics can save lives by fighting bacterial infections. Read about how to use antibiotics and about when not to use antibiotics.

title: Antidepressants
summary: Many people take antidepressants. Learn about antidepressant side effect, the different types of antidepressants, and more.
alternative_names: SSRIs; Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors; Tricyclic antidepressants

title: Antioxidants
summary: Antioxidants can protect cells against free radicals that can cause damage. But there is a lot of misinformation. Get the facts.

title: Anxiety
summary: It's normal to be anxious at times. It may be time to get help if anxiety attack is severe or when anxiety doesn't stop. Learn about anxiety disorders.

title: Aortic Aneurysm
summary: An aneurysm is a bulge or "ballooning" in the wall of an artery. Arteries carry oxygen-rich blood from the heart to the rest of the body. Learn more.

title: Aphasia
summary: Aphasia is a disorder caused by damage to the parts of the brain that control language. It can make it hard for you to read, write, and speak.

title: Aplastic Anemia
summary: Aplastic anemia is a rare but serious blood disorder. If you have it, your bone marrow doesn't make enough new blood cells. Read more on the causes.

title: Appendicitis
summary: You don't have to be young to have appendicitis. Learn to identify signs, symptoms and more about this painful and serious condition.

title: Arm Injuries and Disorders
summary: Arm injuries and arm disorders can be caused by nerve problems, cancers, sprains, dislocations, Tendinitis and conditions such as Arthritis.

title: Arrhythmia
summary: Arrhythmia, also called irregular heartbeat comes in different types. The most common is atrial fibrillation. Read about symptoms and treatment.
alternative_names: Irregular heartbeat

title: Arsenic
summary: Arsenic can be in food, soil, and water. Low levels will probably not hurt you, but higher levels can cause problems. Learn more about arsenic.

title: Arteriovenous Malformations
summary: Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) are defects in your arteries, veins, and capillaries. They are common in the brain and spine. Find out more.
alternative_names: AVM

title: Arthritis
summary: Arthritis can cause pain, swelling and stiffness in and around the joints. Learn about the different types of Arthritis and how they can affect you.

title: Artificial Limbs
summary: Artificial limbs, or prosthetics, can allow a person to do activities they might not be able to do otherwise. Learn more about artificial limbs.

title: Asbestos
summary: Asbestos is the name of a group of minerals with thin fibers. Breathing high levels of asbestos can lead to mesothelioma or lung cancer. Read more.

title: Asian American Health
summary: Asian Americans may have different health issues than the general population. Find out more.

title: Aspergillosis
summary: Find out about symptoms, tests, and treatment of aspergillosis, a disease caused by a fungus.

title: Assisted Living
summary: Many people need help as they age. Assisted living facilities can provide care that you or you loved ones may need. Learn more.
alternative_names: Residential care

title: Assisted Reproductive Technology
summary: Learn about treating infertility with assisted reproductive technology (ART). It includes procedures like in vitro fertilization (IVF).
alternative_names: ART; IVF; In Vitro Fertilization

title: Assistive Devices
summary: Learn about assistive devices and how they can help you if you are disabled or injured.
alternative_names: Assistive technology

title: Asthma
summary: Asthma causes one's airways to become sore and swollen. An attack means a person's lungs are getting less air. Learn about two types of treatment.

title: Asthma in Children
summary: Children's airways are small, making asthma more serious for them. Learn the symptoms, what can cause an attack, and long term treatments.
alternative_names: Childhood asthma; Pediatric asthma

title: Ataxia Telangiectasia
summary: Ataxia Telangiectasia (AT) is an inherited disease that affects several body systems, including the nervous system and immune system. Learn more.

title: Atherosclerosis
summary: Atherosclerosis is hardening and narrowing of the arteries caused by the buildup of a fatty substance called plaque. Learn about the risks and prevention.
alternative_names: Arteriosclerosis

title: Athlete's Foot
summary: Athlete's foot (tinea pedis) is a contagious fungal infection that can affect any part of the foot, but usually begins between the toes. Learn more.
alternative_names: Tinea pedis

title: Atrial Fibrillation
summary: Atrial fibrillation (AF or AFib) is the most common type of arrhythmia (irregular heartbeat). Read about symptoms and treatment.
alternative_names: AF; AFib

title: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder
summary: Does your child have trouble paying attention? This may be a symptom of attention deficit hyperactive disorder (often called ADHD or ADD). Read more.
alternative_names: ADHD

title: Autism Spectrum Disorder
summary: Find out about autism spectrum disorder symptoms, causes, treatment, and other issues related to this developmental disorder.
alternative_names: ASD; Pervasive developmental disorder (PDD)

title: Autoimmune Diseases
summary: Autoimmune diseases are where your immune system attacks healthy cells in your body by mistake. Learn about the symptoms, tests, and treatments.

title: Autonomic Nervous System Disorders
summary: Dysautonomia is a disorder of the autonomic nervous system, which controls functions such as breathing and heartbeat. Read more about these disorders.
alternative_names: Dysautonomia

title: B Vitamins
summary: Do you get enough B vitamins in your diet? Not enough Vitamin B12 or Vitamin B6 can cause anemia. Find out what B vitamins do for your body.

title: Baby Health Checkup
summary: You care about your baby's health. Make sure you get regular checkups for your baby.

title: Back Injuries
summary: Back injuries can affect your range of motion. Common back injuries include sprains and strains, herniated discs and fractured vertebrae.

title: Back Pain
summary: Lumbago is pain on the lower part of your back. Back pain is very common. Treatment varies from medicines to surgery depending on the cause and kind of pain.
alternative_names: Backache; Lumbago

title: Bacterial Infections
summary: There are many types of bacterial infections. Learn about bacterial infections that can make you sick and how to treat them.

title: Bad Breath
summary: There are many reasons why you might have bad breath (also known as halitosis) including a lack of dental hygiene. Learn about how you can prevent it.
alternative_names: Halitosis

title: Balance Problems
summary: Balance problems can be caused by aging, infections, head injury, medications, and other health problems.

title: Barotrauma
summary: Changes in barometric or water pressure can cause injury to your body (Barotrauma). An example is how a change in altitude can make your ears hurt.

title: Bed Bugs
summary: Bed bugs - ugh! Also known as bedbugs, these critters bite and can make you itchy. Discover how to get rid of them, how to treat bites, and more.

title: Behcet's Syndrome
summary: Behcet’s syndrome (or disease) causes inflammation of the blood vessels and symptoms in many parts of the body. Learn about diagnosis and treatment.
alternative_names: Behcet's disease

title: Bell's Palsy
summary: Bell's palsy is the most common cause of facial paralysis. Symptoms appear suddenly and can range from mild to severe. Find out if you are at risk.

title: Benefits of Exercise
summary: Regular exercise is one of the best things you can do for your health. Learn about all of the benefits, plus tips on adding exercise to your routine.

title: Benign Tumors
summary: You may be relieved when your doctor tells you a tumor is benign. But they may need to be removed. Find out more about benign tumors.
alternative_names: Benign neoplasms; Noncancerous tumors

title: Bereavement
summary: Losing someone you love is difficult. Everyone grieves differently. Get support for bereavement and learn more.
alternative_names: Grief

title: Bile Duct Cancer
summary: Bile duct cancer can be caused by liver diseases or colitis. Learn about bile duct cancer tests, diagnosis, treatment, and survival rates.
alternative_names: Cholangiocarcinoma

title: Bile Duct Diseases
summary: Infections, gallstones, and cancer can result in bile duct problems. Discover the types, causes, symptoms, and treatment of bile duct diseases.

title: Biodefense and Bioterrorism
summary: Learn about and prepare for bioterrorism.  Biodefense  includes vaccines and other methods to protect against bioterrorism.

title: Biopsy
summary: If your doctor suspects you may have cancer or another disease, she may order a biopsy for you. Learn about the types of biopsies and more.

title: Bipolar Disorder
summary: Bipolar disorder is a mood disorder that can cause intense mood swings. It's also called manic depression. Learn about the types, symptoms, treatment, and more.
alternative_names: Manic depression; Manic-depressive illness

title: Bird Flu
summary: The bird flu (also known as influenza A or the avian flu) primarily infects birds, but can pose health risks to people. Learn how to avoid this flu.
alternative_names: Avian flu; Avian influenza; H5N1; H7N9

title: Birth Control
summary: Birth control, or contraception, is designed to prevent pregnancy. Read about the different options and their risks and benefits.
alternative_names: Contraception

title: Birth Defects
summary: A birth defect is a problem that happens while a baby is developing in the mother's body.  Learn about the different types of birth defects, their treatments, and how some kinds can be prevented.

title: Birth Weight
summary: Newborn babies vary in birth weight and size. Some low birth babies may have health issues. Get the facts on your baby's birth weight.

title: Birthmarks
summary: Birthmarks can be two main types: vascular, such as hemangiomas and port wine stains or pigmented, such as a mole or Mongolian spot. Find out more.
alternative_names: Cafe au lait spot; Hemangioma; Mongolian spot; Nevus; Strawberry mark

title: Black and African American Health
summary: Black and African American health disparities and access to healthcare are among the issues concerning the health of Blacks and African Americans. Learn more.

title: Bladder Cancer
summary: Bladder cancer symptoms range from lower back pain to blood in your urine. Read about important risk factors and find a list of treatments available

title: Bladder Diseases
summary: Many conditions can affect your bladder and put you at risk for bladder diseases. Read about some of the common bladder pains which includes Cystitis

title: Bleeding
summary: Bleeding is the loss of blood, inside or outside the body. A hemorrhage is severe bleeding. Learn about the causes of bleeding and how to treat it.
alternative_names: Hematoma; Hemorrhage

title: Bleeding Disorders
summary: With bleeding disorders, there is a problem with blood clotting. It may be hard to stop the bleeding. Read about bleeding disorders and treatments.
alternative_names: Clotting disorders

title: Blisters
summary: Blisters are fluid-filled sacs on the outer layer of your skin. They form because of rubbing, heat, or skin diseases. Learn about how to prevent them.
alternative_names: Bulla; Vesicle

title: Blood
summary: Blood has many functions in your body. Blood tests help doctors check for certain diseases and conditions. Learn about blood types and blood tests.

title: Blood Clots
summary: Your blood forms clots to stop bleeding. Some people get too many clots or their blood clots abnormally. Learn about the causes and treatments.
alternative_names: Hypercoagulability

title: Blood Count Tests
summary: Blood count tests help doctors check for certain diseases and conditions. Learn about blood count tests, like the complete blood count (CBC).
alternative_names: CBC; Complete Blood Count; Hematologic Tests

title: Blood Disorders
summary: Blood disorders affect one or more parts of the blood and prevent your blood from doing its job. Find out about the types, causes, and treatments.
alternative_names: Hematologic diseases

title: Blood Glucose
summary: Your body processes the food you eat into glucose. Your blood carries glucose (blood sugar) to all of your body's cells to use for energy. Learn more.
alternative_names: Blood sugar

title: Blood Pressure Medicines
summary: If lifestyle changes do not help to control or lower high blood pressure (hypertension), your health care provider may prescribe blood pressure medicines.
alternative_names: Antihypertensive medicines; High blood pressure medicines

title: Blood Thinners
summary: Anticoagulant and antiplatelet drugs are blood thinners. They reduce risk of heart attacks and help keep blood clots from forming. Learn more.
alternative_names: Anti-platelet drugs; Anticoagulants

title: Blood Transfusion and Donation
summary: Get information on blood donation, the blood donation process, and blood transfusion.

title: Body Lice
summary: Body lice are parasitic insects. They spread through physical contact with a person who has body lice or though contact with their clothing. They are most common in homeless people. Find out how to kn

title: Body Weight
summary: Do you know what the ideal body weight is for your gender and height? Find information and tools to help you learn more about your body weight.

title: Bone Cancer
summary: Bone cancer comes in three types: Osteosarcoma, Chondrosarcoma, and Ewing's sarcoma. Learn how bone cancer is diagnosed and treated.

title: Bone Density
summary: Bone density or bone mineral density (BMD) is the amount of bone mineral in your bones. A BMD test measures bone health and risk for breaking bones.
alternative_names: Bone mass

title: Bone Diseases
summary: Bone diseases increase your risk for breaking bones. Learn about different kinds of bone problems and how genetics can play a role.

title: Bone Grafts
summary: A bone graft is a surgical procedure where bone tissue is transplanted from your body or a donor's. Bone grafts repair diseased bones and bone loss.

title: Bone Infections
summary: Osteomyelitis is a bone infection. Learn about who is at risk for osteomyelitis and how these bone infections are treated and diagnosed.

title: Bone Marrow Diseases
summary: Bone marrow diseases affect your body's ability to make healthy blood cells. Learn the different causes and possible treatments.

title: Bone Marrow Transplantation
summary: Bone marrow transplantation replaces faulty bone marrow with healthy bone marrow from a donor. Learn about the possible risks, and procedure.

title: Botox
summary: Botox injections can be used to temporarily reduce wrinkles but can also treat other health problems such as severe sweating or lazy-eye. Learn how.
alternative_names: Botulinum toxin type A

title: Botulism
summary: Botulism is caused by a bacteria. It can be serious. Find out about symptoms, causes, how to prevent it.

title: Bowel Incontinence
summary: Learn about causes, treatment, and control of bowel incontinence. This condition is also called fecal incontinence.
alternative_names: Encopresis; Fecal incontinence; Stool soiling

title: Bowel Movement
summary: Bowel movements have many names but it's all the same. Everyone has BMs.  Some are normal and some are irregular. Learn more.
alternative_names: BM; Feces; Poop; Stool

title: Brachial Plexus Injuries
summary: Brachial plexus injuries occur due to shoulder trauma, tumors, or inflammation. Some injuries heal without treatment, others need PT or surgery.

title: Brain Aneurysm
summary: A brain aneurysm is a bulge or ballooning in a blood vessel in the brain. It is life-threatening it if bursts. Learn about the signs and symptoms.
alternative_names: Berry aneurysm; Cerebral aneurysm; Intracranial aneurysm

title: Brain Diseases
summary: Brain diseases affect different functions of the body from memory, speech, thinking clearly, how well the different organs work, or even movement.

title: Brain Malformations
summary: Brain malformations is damage or abnormal development of the brain and nervous system. Starts long before a baby is born. Learn types and treatments.
alternative_names: Cephalic disorders

title: Brain Tumors
summary: A brain tumor is a growth of abnormal cells in the brain tissue. Learn the types of tumors, symptoms, how they are diagnosed and treatment options.

title: Breast Cancer
summary: Breast cancer is the second most common type of cancer in women in the US. Mammograms are the best way to find breast cancer early, when it is easier to treat.

title: Breast Diseases
summary: Breast changes such as lumps, bumps, and discharge are common. Some causes can be aging, hormones, or medicines. Learn about symptoms and treatments.

title: Breast Reconstruction
summary: Breast reconstruction can rebuild the shape of the breast after a mastectomy for breast cancer. Read about the types of implants and how it is done.

title: Breastfeeding
summary: Breastfeeding gives your baby the right nutrients and may protect your baby against some illness. Learn about all its benefits and how to breastfeed.
alternative_names: Lactation; Nursing

title: Breathing Problems
summary: When you have breathing problems, such as shortness of breath, it's hard for you to take in the oxygen your body needs.  Find out what can cause this.

title: Bronchial Disorders
summary: The bronchi are two tubes that carry air to your lungs. Problems with the bronchi include bronchitis, bronchiectasis, and bronchiolitis. Learn more.

title: Bruises
summary: Learn about how bruises, or contusions, form. They happen when you get a blow or injury that breaks the small blood vessels under the skin.
alternative_names: Contusion; Ecchymoses

title: Bullying and Cyberbullying
summary: Bullying is when a person or group repeatedly harms someone on purpose. Cyberbullying is bullying that happens through text messages or online. Both can cause lasting harm. Learn the signs of bullying, and how to help a child who is being bullied.

title: Burns
summary: A burn is damage to your body's tissues caused by heat, chemicals, electricity, sunlight, or radiation. Read about the different types and treatments.

title: Bursitis
summary: Bursitis is inflammation of fluid sacs between your joints. Bursitis symptoms include pain and swelling. Learn about how to relieve bursitis symptoms.

title: C. diff Infections
summary: C. diff or C. difficile is a bacterium that causes diarrhea. You are more likely to get C. diff if you take antibiotics or are an older adult.
alternative_names: Clostridioides difficile infections; Clostridium difficile Infections; Clostridium enterocolitis; Pseudomembranous colitis

title: Caffeine
summary: Many people enjoy a cup of coffee or tea to give them a boost. But is it safe? Learn more about caffeine.

title: Calcium
summary: Your body needs calcium for many reasons. Learn what foods are high in calcium and how much calcium you need in a healthy diet.

title: Campylobacter Infections
summary: If you have diarrhea, bloating, and vomiting, you may have a campylobacter infection. How do you get it? How can you treat it? Learn more.

title: Cancer
summary: If you or someone you love has been diagnosed with cancer, learn about diagnosis, treatment, risk factors, and much more.
alternative_names: Carcinoma; Malignancy; Neoplasms; Tumor

title: Cancer Alternative Therapies
summary: There are options to consider when deciding about cancer treatment. Cancer alternative therapies may help.  Learn more.

title: Cancer Chemotherapy
summary: Chemotherapy may help you fight cancer. Find out about the  types of chemotherapy, side effects, and the latest news about chemotherapy.

title: Cancer Immunotherapy
summary: Immunotherapy is a cancer treatment that helps your immune system fight cancer. Learn about the different types, including targeted therapy.

title: Cancer in Children
summary: You will have a lot of questions if your child is diagnosed with cancer. Many cancers in children can be treated. Learn about childhood cancers.

title: Cancer--Living with Cancer
summary: Living with cancer is not easy. It can take a physical and emotional toll on your health. Learn how to cope with cancer in your daily life.

title: Canker Sores
summary: Canker sores (Aphthous ulcers) are painful sores inside of the mouth. They are non-cancerous but can cause viral infections. Read about the triggers.
alternative_names: Aphthous ulcers

title: Carbohydrate Metabolism Disorders
summary: Carbs include sugar, starch, and fiber. Some disorders affect how your body uses these nutrients, causing health problems. Learn more.

title: Carbohydrates
summary: Carbohydrates are one of the basic food groups. Learn how to incorporate carbohydrates into a healthy diet.
alternative_names: Carbs

title: Carbon Monoxide Poisoning
summary: Carbon monoxide is known as the silent killer. It is a deadly gas that has no color or smell. Protect yourself and your family by learning more.
alternative_names: CO poisoning

title: Carcinoid Tumors
summary: Carcinoid tumors can happen in the lungs or digestive tract. Learn about risk factors, tests, treatment, and more.

title: Cardiac Rehabilitation
summary: Cardiac rehabilitation (rehab) is a program to help you get better after heart problems or heart surgery.  Learn what it includes and how it can help.

title: Cardiomyopathy
summary: Cardiomyopathy is a disease that causes the heart to become enlarged, thick, or stiff. Read about the different types, their symptoms, and treatments.
alternative_names: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy; Dilated cardiomyopathy; Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy; Myocardiopathy; Restrictive cardiomyopathy

title: Caregiver Health
summary: Caregiving can be rewarding, but it may also be stressful and sometimes even overwhelming. Learn how to prevent or relieve caregiver stress.
alternative_names: Caring for the caregiver

title: Caregivers
summary: Are you a caregiver? If so, you may have to help with cooking, paying bills, and more. Learn about caregiving and how to find support for yourself.

title: Carotid Artery Disease
summary: In carotid artery disease, a waxy substance (plaque) clogs the arteries that bring blood to your brain and head. Find out how it cause a stroke.

title: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
summary: Is the numbness and pain in your arm and wrist a passing cramp or carpal tunnel syndrome? Learn about carpal tunnel syndrome symptoms and treatment.
alternative_names: Median nerve entrapment

title: Cartilage Disorders
summary: Cartilage covers the ends of your bones. Sports injuries and other disorders can cause cartilage problems. Learn how to take care of your cartilage.

title: Cat Scratch Disease
summary: If you feel sick after a you have been scratched or bitten by a cat, you may have cat scratch disease, also called cat scratch fever. Find out more.
alternative_names: CSD; Cat scratch fever

title: Cataract
summary: A cataract is a clouding of the lens in your eye. It affects your vision. Cataracts are very common in older people. Learn about symptoms and surgery.

title: Celiac Disease
summary: Coping with celiac disease can be challenging. Learn about gluten-free diets, signs and symptoms, tests, and more.
alternative_names: Celiac sprue; Gluten-sensitive enteropathy; Nontropical sprue

title: Cellulitis
summary: Cellulitis is an infection of the skin and deep underlying tissues. The cause is usually a type of strep bacteria. Learn about symptoms and treatment.

title: Cerebellar Disorders
summary: Cerebellar disorders are problems with the cerebellum, an area of the brain that controls coordination and balance. Ataxias is one of these disorders.

title: Cerebral Palsy
summary: Cerebral palsy, CP happens when areas of the brain that control movement and posture do not develop correctly or get damaged. Treatment can improve.
alternative_names: CP

title: Cervical Cancer
summary: The cervix is the lower part of a woman's uterus. Most cervical cancer is caused by the HPV virus. It can often be cured if found early - learn how.

title: Cervical Cancer Screening
summary: Cervical cancer is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). Reduce your risk of cervical cancer by having regular screening tests, and getting vaccinated against HPV.

title: Cervix Disorders
summary: The cervix is the lower part of a woman's uterus. Read about problems that can affect the cervix, like cervicitis (inflammation) and cervical polyps.

title: Cesarean Delivery
summary: Learn about Cesarean delivery (C-section), surgery to deliver a baby through the mother's abdomen. It is done when a vaginal birth is not safe.
alternative_names: C-section; Cesarean section

title: Chagas Disease
summary: Chagas disease, also called American trypanosomiasis, is a disease caused by a parasite. It is mainly spread by kissing bugs, which are common in Latin America. It is important to get early treatment. Learn about the signs and symptoms.
alternative_names: American trypanosomiasis; South American trypanosomiasis

title: Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease
summary: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, CMT affects your peripheral nerves. Interrupting messages to your brain about things around you, like touch.
alternative_names: Hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy; Peroneal muscular atrophy

title: Chemical Emergencies
summary: Are you prepared for a chemical emergency? Find out.

title: Chest Injuries and Disorders
summary: Your chest is packed with vital organs, like the esophagus, lungs, and heart. Learn about the different types of chest injuries and chest disorders.

title: Chest Pain
summary: Chest pain can be caused by a heart attack, but it can have other causes. Learn about what they are, and when you should get immediate medical help.

title: Chiari Malformation
summary: Chiari Malformation (CMs) is a congenital condition in which brain tissue extends to the spinal canal. Learn about the different types and symptoms.
alternative_names: Arnold-Chiari Malformation

title: Chickenpox
summary: Chickenpox is a contagious disease caused by the varicella-zoster virus. It causes an itchy rash with blisters. Learn about vaccines and treatment.
alternative_names: Varicella

title: Chikungunya
summary: Mosquitoes carry the Chikungunya virus. Learn about Chikungunya prevention, symptoms, treatment, and more.

title: Child Abuse
summary: Child abuse can have many forms. It can have long lasting emotional effects. Learn about child abuse.

title: Child Behavior Disorders
summary: Is your child showing aggression, hostility, or other disruptive behaviors? Learn about childhood behavior disorders and how to help your child.
alternative_names: Conduct disorders

title: Child Dental Health
summary: Healthy teeth and gums are important to your child's overall health. Good dental habits and proper oral care can help prevent tooth decay and cavities.

title: Child Development
summary: Ever wonder what's "normal" for your child? Child development includes physical, intellectual, social, and emotional changes. Learn more.

title: Child Mental Health
summary: It's important to recognize and treat mental illnesses in children early on. Learn about warning signs, tests, and therapies.

title: Child Nutrition
summary: What should be on your kid's plate? A healthy diet helps children grow and learn. Learn more about nutrition for children.

title: Child Safety
summary: What steps should you take to ensure your child's safety? Get specifics on safety for kids.

title: Child Sexual Abuse
summary: Sexual abuse is one form of child abuse.  It includes a wide range of actions between a child and an adult or older child. Learn the facts.

title: Childbirth
summary: Childbirth is the process of having a baby. Learn about the 3 stages of labor, and how you can prepare, tell if you are in labor, and manage the pain.

title: Childbirth Problems
summary: Complications may happen during childbirth including preterm labor, problems with the umbilical cord or position of the baby, and birth injuries.

title: Childhood Brain Tumors
summary: Childhood brain tumors are abnormal growths inside the skull of children. Even benign tumors can be serious. Learn when a child should see a doctor.

title: Childhood Leukemia
summary: Leukemia is cancer of the white blood cells, it is the most common type of childhood cancer. Learn about the symptoms, and treatment options.

title: Childhood Vaccines
summary: Childhood vaccines, or immunizations, protect your children from many serious or even deadly diseases. Learn why and when you should vaccinate your children.
alternative_names: Shots

title: Children's Health
summary: Most parents know the basics of keeping their child healthy, but what else do you need to know? Learn about issues related to your kid's health.

title: Chiropractic
summary: Chiropractic is a health care profession. Chiropractors perform manipulations to the spine or other parts of the body. Read more.

title: Chlamydia Infections
summary: Chlamydia is a common sexually transmitted disease contracted by men and women. Chlamydia usually does not have symptoms. Learn about tests and prevention.

title: Choking
summary: Do you know how to respond if you see someone choking? Learn how to respond with back blows, the Heimlich maneuver (abdominal thrusts), and CPR.

title: Cholera
summary: Cholera is a bacterial infection that causes diarrhea caused by bacteria usually found in contaminated water. Learn about symptoms and treatment.

title: Cholesterol
summary: Your body needs some cholesterol, but too much can raise your risk of heart disease. Know the types (HDL and LDL), and how to lower high cholesterol.
alternative_names: Hypercholesterolemia; Hyperlipidemia; Hyperlipoproteinemia

title: Cholesterol Levels: What You Need to Know
summary: High cholesterol levels can put you at risk of heart diseases. It's important to get regular cholesterol tests and make sure your levels are in a healthy range.

title: Cholesterol Medicines
summary: If diet and exercise don't reduce your cholesterol levels enough, you may need to take medicine. Learn about the different types of cholesterol medicines.

title: Choosing a Doctor or Health Care Service
summary: We all want high-quality health care, but it's hard to know how to choose. Learn about specific things to consider when finding a doctor.

title: Chronic Bronchitis
summary: Bronchitis is an inflammation of the airways that carry air to your lungs. Chronic bronchitis is a long-term condition. Discover symptoms and treatment.

title: Chronic Kidney Disease
summary: If your kidneys are damaged and can't filter blood easily, then you may suffer from chronic kidney disease (CKD). Read about the treatments available
alternative_names: CKD

title: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
summary: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia or CLL is cancer of the white blood cells, where abnormal cells are made.  This makes it hard for the blood to do its work.
alternative_names: CLL

title: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
summary: Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is a cancer of the white blood cells. It usually affects older adults. Learn about symptoms, genetics, and treatment.
alternative_names: CML; Chronic granulocytic leukemia; Chronic myelogenous leukemia

title: Chronic Pain
summary: Experiencing ongoing pain is called chronic pain. While chronic pain cannot be cured, there are treatments that can help manage and reduce.

title: Circumcision
summary: Circumcision is the removal of the foreskin, the skin that covers the tip of the penis. Read about the medical benefits and risks to circumcision.

title: Cirrhosis
summary: Cirrhosis is caused when scar tissue replaces healthy tissue in the liver because of chronic injury. Learn how cirrhosis is diagnosed and treated.
alternative_names: Hepatic fibrosis

title: Cleaning, Disinfecting, and Sanitizing
summary: To avoid becoming infected by germs from surfaces and objects, it is important to wash your hands often. It’s also important to regularly clean and disinfect surfaces and objects. Learn the difference between cleaning, disinfecting and sanitizing.

title: Cleft Lip and Palate
summary: During early pregnancy stages your child may develop cleft lip or cleft palate. Find out when you should have surgery to fix the cleft lip and palate.

title: Climate Change
summary: Climate change is more than global warming.  It's major change in temperature, rainfall, snow, or wind patterns. Read how it can affect your health.

title: Clinical Trials
summary: Did you ever wonder how doctors find out if a treatment is effective? Clinical trials test how well new medical approaches work in people. Read more.

title: Cloning
summary: Cloning is the process of creating an exact genetic replica of a cell, tissue or organism. Learn about the types and uses in medicine.

title: Club Drugs
summary: Club drugs are group of psychoactive drugs popular at bars, night clubs, and raves. They include MDMA (Ecstasy), GHB, and others. Learn more.

title: Cocaine
summary: Cocaine, also called crack cocaine, is a highly addictive stimulant. It can be snorted, injected, or smoked. Learn about health effects and treatment.
alternative_names: Blow; Coca; Coke; Crack; Flake; Snow; Soda Cot

title: Cochlear Implants
summary: A cochlear implant can help individuals who are severely hard of hearing or deaf. A cochlear implant does not restore normal hearing.

title: Cold and Cough Medicines
summary: There are lots of different cold and cough medicines, and they do different things. Learn about different remedies and when you should take them.

title: Cold Sores
summary: Learn about types of herpes simplex. Type 1 causes cold sores, fever blisters or oral herpes. Type 2 affects the genital area. Read about symptoms.
alternative_names: Fever blister; Oral herpes

title: Collapsed Lung
summary: There are two types of collapsed lung: pneumothorax (a total collapse) and atelectasis (partial collapse). Learn the symptoms, causes, and treatment.

title: College Health
summary: College can bring excitement, challenges, and new responsibility.  Learn what steps students can take to stay healthy and safe in college.

title: Colonic Diseases
summary: Diseases of the large intestine can affect your colon's ability to work properly. See how diet, medicines, and in some cases surgery can help.
alternative_names: Large intestine diseases

title: Colonic Polyps
summary: Colorectal polyps are extra clumps of tissue that grow in the colon. Some polyps can become cancerous but most are not. Details on several types here.
alternative_names: Colon polyps

title: Colonoscopy
summary: A colonoscopy is an exam of the colon and rectum using a tiny camera to search for polyps, cancer or other diseases. Follow these tips to prepare.

title: Color Blindness
summary: If you have color blindness, you can't see the difference between certain colors. It is more common in men. Learn about genetics and how to adjust.

title: Colorectal Cancer
summary: Colorectal cancer starts in the colon or rectum. It may not cause symptoms at first. Screening tests can help find it early, when treatment is most effective.
alternative_names: Colon cancer; Rectal cancer

title: Coma
summary: Coma is a state of unconsciousness, where one is alive but cannot move or respond. Outcome depends on the cause, severity, and site of the damage.

title: Common Cold
summary: Common cold symptoms usually begin 2 or 3 days after infection and last 2 to 14 days. There is no cure for the common cold. Learn tips for relief.

title: Common Infant and Newborn Problems
summary: It is hard when your baby is sick, many problems are not serious. Learn about how to help your baby, and warning signs for more serious issues.

title: Complementary and Integrative Medicine
summary: Complementary and Integrative Medicine, also called alternative medicine includes treatments that are not part of mainstream medicine. Read more.
alternative_names: CAM

title: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome
summary: Complex regional pain syndrome, CRPS or Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy, RSD are chronic pain conditions. They cause intense pain and can spread.
alternative_names: CRPS; Causalgia; Reflex sympathetic dystrophy

title: Compulsive Gambling
summary: Many people enjoy gambling, but some lose control. If you think you might have a gambling addiction, talk to your health care provider for help.
alternative_names: Gambling addiction

title: Concussion
summary: Concussion, a minor injury to the brain due to a blow or hit to the head. Symptoms may not show up right away. Learn when to see your doctor.
alternative_names: Brain concussion

title: Congenital Heart Defects
summary: Congenital heart defects, problems with the structure of the heart, are the most common type of birth defect. Learn about diagnosis and treatment.

title: Connective Tissue Disorders
summary: There are over 200 disorders that affect connective tissues. Examples include cellulitis, scars, and osteogenesis imperfecta. Learn more.

title: Constipation
summary: Feeling "backed-up" or like you need to "go" but just can't? Read some of the reasons why this could be happening and learn some prevention tips.

title: COPD
summary: COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) makes it hard for you to breathe. At first symptoms are mild, but usually become more severe. Learn more.

title: Coping with Chronic Illness
